elements.name: adult_consent
elements.html:
Instructions: Please read the following consent information out loud to the respondent and have them orally give their consent to you.

Unsheltered Point-in-Time Count 2026

UW Researchers:

  • Dr. Zack W. Almquist
    Associate Professor, Department of Sociology
    zalmquist@uw.edu
  • Dr. Amy Hagopian
    Professor Emeritus, Global Health
    Professor Emeritus, Health Systems and Population Health
    Director, Community Oriented Public Health Practice
    hagopian@uw.edu
  • Dr. June Yang
    Research Scientist, Center for Studies in Demography and Ecology (CSDE) & eScience Institute
    jyang32@uw.edu

Researcher's Statement

We are asking you to be in a research study. The purpose of this consent form is to give you the information you will need to help you decide whether to be in the study or not. Please read the form carefully. You may ask questions about the purpose of the research, what we would ask you to do, the possible risks and benefits, your rights as a volunteer, and anything else about the research or this form that is not clear. When we have answered all your questions, you can decide if you want to be in the study or not. This process is called "informed consent." We will give you a copy of this form for your records.

This is a research study focused on innovating better methods to enumerate individuals experiencing homelessness. This study is led by Drs. Zack W. Almquist, Amy Hagopian and June Yang at the University of Washington. We hope to learn more about the number and demographics of individuals' experiencing homelessness through their social networks. You are being asked to take part in this study as a person currently experiencing homelessness.

Key Information

  • Taking part is your choice.
  • If you join, we will ask you to do a 10–15 minute survey about your housing, health, and people you know who are also experiencing homelessness.
  • You will receive a $20 cash card or electronic payment for doing the survey, and $5 for each person you successfully recruit (up to three people).
  • Questions may feel personal (for example, about health, substance use, or housing history). You can skip any question or stop at any time and still get paid.
  • We will keep your information confidential to the extent allowed by law. We will ask for some limited identifying information so we don't count you twice and so we can contact you for possible follow-up. We will store this information securely, separate from your survey answers.
  • If you later decide to stop, we will stop collecting new information from you, but we will keep and continue to use data already collected, including any data that have already been de-identified and combined with other participants.

Please read the sections below for more detail.

PURPOSE OF THE STUDY

The purpose of this study is to collect information about the number and characteristics of people who are currently experiencing homelessness. We also want to investigate the timing and social networks of people who are currently unhoused.

STUDY PROCEDURES

To better understand the number of people experiencing homelessness, their demographics and social networks, we will survey household heads 18 and older.

This study is being done in the form of a survey. If you decide to participate in the survey, you will be asked to discuss your experiences with homelessness and social networks of people you know who are also experiencing homelessness. It will take about 10 minutes to complete the survey.

Risks: Risks of this study are minimal, though there are questions which inquire about personal and/or sensitive content. Participants can refuse to answer any question or discontinue the interview at any point without repercussion. Every effort will be made to keep responses confidential, and responses will not affect any of your current or subsequent benefits.

Benefits: Participation in this study will contribute to shared knowledge on homelessness from those who are experiencing it first-hand.

Compensation: Participants will receive a $20 prepaid visa card after completing the survey questionnaire. We will also give you a $5 gift card for each person (also experiencing homelessness) who you recruit to participate in this study (up to three people/gift cards).

Voluntary Participation: Your participation in this study is voluntary. You can decide to participate or not to participate, or to withdraw at any time without penalty or loss of benefits to which you are entitled.

What happens to the information collected for the research?

We will not keep any personal identifying information about you after the study period.

The data we collect will be confidential. We will protect the privacy of the participants by coding all data sheets and files with a participant identification number. If we learn that the participant intends to harm themselves or others, however, we are legally obligated to report that to a mental health official.

Sometimes government or university staff review studies like this to make sure they are being done safely and legally. If a review takes place, they may look at study records. They will protect your privacy, and your information will not be used to put you at legal risk.

DATA RETENTION AND WITHDRAWAL

Because this is a multi-year project, we need to keep your data for some time.

We will keep your survey answers and the link between your name/contact information and your study ID for as long as needed to:

  • Finish this study,
  • Conduct closely related studies about homelessness, and
  • Meet University of Washington and state/federal records-retention rules (these rules generally require keeping data for several years after a study ends).

We may use your de-identified survey data (data with names and direct contact information removed) in future research related to homelessness and housing. We may also share de-identified data with other researchers under formal data-sharing agreements. Your name and direct contact information will not be shared with other researchers without additional IRB approval or your additional consent.

What if I withdraw from the study?

If you decide to stop participating, we will stop collecting new information from you and will not contact you again for this study (unless you later tell us you want to re-join).

However, we will keep and continue to use the information already collected about you, including any data that have already been de-identified and combined with others. Once your data are combined and analyzed, they cannot be separated out.

We will also keep certain identifiers (such as your date of birth and name initials) and the code that links those to your survey ID, as allowed by UW policy and law. Because we keep these identifiers even if you withdraw, you may decide that you do not want to participate.

What will be shared with others?

We may share group-level results (for example, "X% of people report Y") with KCRHA, local governments, HUD, community organizations, and in academic publications.

Your name or direct contact information will not appear in any reports or publications.

Whom can I talk to?

If you have any questions or concerns about this project, you may contact:

  • Dr. Zack Almquist – zalmquis@uw.edu
  • Dr. Amy Hagopian – hagopian@uw.edu
  • Dr. June Yang – jyang32@uw.edu

If you have questions about your rights as a research subject or complaints about the research, contact:

Human Subjects Division (HSD) – University of Washington
Phone: (206) 543-0098
Email: hsdinfo@uw.edu

CONSENT

Participation in research is voluntary. You may refuse to participate or stop at any time without penalty or loss of benefits to which you are entitled.

By agreeing below, you are saying:

  • This study has been explained to you.
  • You have had the chance to ask questions.
  • You understand that you can stop at any time.
  • You voluntarily agree to take part in this research.

elements.name: youth_consent
elements.html:
Instructions: Please read the following consent information out loud to the respondent and have them orally give their consent to you.

Unsheltered Point-in-Time Count 2026

UW Researchers:

  • Dr. Zack W. Almquist
    Associate Professor, Department of Sociology
    zalmquist@uw.edu
  • Dr. Amy Hagopian
    Professor Emeritus, Global Health
    Professor Emeritus, Health Systems and Population Health
    Director, Community Oriented Public Health Practice
    hagopian@uw.edu
  • Dr. June Yang
    Research Scientist, Center for Studies in Demography and Ecology (CSDE) & eScience Institute
    jyang32@uw.edu

Why are we talking to you?

We are doing a research study to learn more about young people who are experiencing homelessness or unstable housing. We want to understand how many youth are in this situation, what their lives are like, and how their friendships and social networks work.

We are asking you to be in this study because you are a young person who is currently experiencing homelessness or unstable housing.

Taking part is your choice.

Key things to know:

  • If you join, we will ask you to do a survey that takes about 10–15 minutes.
  • The survey will ask about:
    • Your housing situation
    • Your health
    • People you know who are also experiencing homelessness or unstable housing
  • You will get a $20 prepaid card for doing the survey.
  • You can also receive $5 for each person you successfully recruit (up to three people) who is also experiencing homelessness or unstable housing and who chooses to do the survey.
  • Some questions may feel personal (for example, about health, substance use, or your housing history).
  • You can skip any question you do not want to answer.
  • You can stop at any time, and you will still get your payment for the survey.
  • We will keep your information private as much as the law allows.
  • We will not share your answers with parents/guardians, teachers, case workers, or shelter staff unless we are worried that you or someone else is in serious danger.

What is the purpose of this study?

The purpose of this study is to:

  • Learn more about how many people are experiencing homelessness.
  • Understand what life is like for youth who are unhoused or unstably housed.
  • Learn how social networks (the people you know) are connected to homelessness.

This information may help community organizations and local leaders plan better services and support for youth.

What will happen if you join?

If you decide to be in the study:

  • A researcher will explain the study and answer any questions you have.
  • You will do a survey (on a tablet, phone, or paper, or read aloud if you prefer).
  • The survey will ask you about:
    • Your age and basic background
    • Your current and past housing situation
    • Your health and well-being
    • People you know who are also experiencing homelessness or unstable housing
  • The survey will take about 10–15 minutes.
  • You can take breaks, skip any questions you don't like, or stop at any time.

Are there any risks or discomforts?

Some questions may feel personal, sad, or uncomfortable (for example, questions about your housing situation, substance use, or hard life experiences).

You might feel upset when thinking or talking about these topics.

  • You do not have to answer any question you do not want to answer.
  • You can stop the survey at any time, for any reason.
  • If you become upset, we can pause, stop, or help connect you with local resources if available.

Will you be paid?

Yes.

  • You will get a $20 prepaid visa card or electronic payment after you complete the survey.
  • You can also receive $5 for each person (up to three people) you recruit who is also experiencing homelessness or unstable housing and who decides to do the survey.
  • Even if you decide to stop the survey early, you will still receive the $20 for participating.

Will your answers be kept private?

We will do our best to keep your information private:

  • We will give you a study ID number instead of using your name on the survey.
  • Your name and any contact information (like phone or email) will be stored separately from your survey answers.
  • Only the research team, individuals from the UW, or other agencies that may need to audit study records will have access to the link between your name and your survey ID, and this will be kept in secure, password-protected files.

However, there are a few important exceptions:

  • If you tell us that you plan to seriously hurt yourself or hurt someone else, we must tell someone who can help keep you or others safe.
  • Because you are a young person, if you tell us that an adult is hurting you, abusing you, or neglecting you, we are required by law to report this to a person or agency who can help keep you safe.
  • Sometimes government or university staff check studies like this to make sure they are being done safely and legally. If they review this study, they may look at study records, but they will protect your privacy, and your information will not be used to get you in trouble with the law.

What happens to your information after the study?

Because this is a multi-year project, we need to keep your data for some time.

We will keep your survey answers and the link between your name/contact information and your study ID for as long as needed to:

  • Finish this study
  • Do closely related studies about homelessness
  • Meet University of Washington and state/federal rules for how long we must keep research records

We may use your de-identified survey data (data with your name and contact information removed) in future research about homelessness and housing. We may share de-identified data with other researchers, but your name and direct contact information will not be shared without additional approval and/or your additional consent.

What if you change your mind?

Being in this study is voluntary.

  • You can say no to being in the study.
  • If you start and then change your mind, you can stop at any time.
  • If you stop, we will not collect new information from you or contact you again for this study (unless you later tell us you want to re-join).

However:

  • We will keep and continue to use information already collected about you, including any data that have already been de-identified and combined with other participants. Once your data are combined and analyzed, they cannot be separated out.
  • We may keep certain basic identifiers (such as your date of birth and initials) and the code that links those to your study ID, as allowed by UW policy and law.
  • You can decide if you are comfortable with this before you agree to participate.

What will be shared with others?

We may share group-level results (for example, "X% of youth reported Y") with:

  • King County Regional Homelessness Authority (KCRHA)
  • Local governments
  • HUD (the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development)
  • Community organizations
  • In academic papers or presentations

Your name or direct contact information will never appear in any reports or publications.

Whom can you talk to?

If you have questions or concerns about the study, you can contact:

  • Dr. Zack Almquist – zalmquis@uw.edu
  • Dr. Amy Hagopian – hagopian@uw.edu
  • Dr. June Yang – jyang32@uw.edu

If you have questions about your rights as someone in a research study or complaints about the research, you can contact:

Human Subjects Division (HSD) – University of Washington
Phone: (206) 543-0098
Email: hsdinfo@uw.edu

Your choice (Assent)

Taking part in this research is your choice. You may refuse to participate or stop at any time without penalty or loss of benefits to which you are entitled.

By agreeing, you are saying:

  • Someone explained this study to you in a way you understand.
  • You had a chance to ask questions.
  • Your questions were answered.
  • You understand that you can stop at any time.
  • You want to be in this study.

elements.name: consent_given
elements.title: Do you consent to participate in this survey?

elements.name: first_two_letters_fname
elements.title: Enter the first two letters of the respondent's first name

validators.text: Please enter the first two letters of the respondent's first name.

elements.name: first_two_letters_lname
elements.title: Enter the first two letters of the respondent's last name

validators.text: Please enter the first two letters of the respondent's last name.

elements.name: date_of_birth
elements.title: Enter the respondent's date of birth

elements.name: survey_churn_prioryr
elements.title: Did you participate in a similar survey as this survey (e.g., received a coupon) in January 2024 in this same city?

elements.name: survey_churn_seed
elements.title: In 2024, did you receive a coupon from a care worker or navigator (this was referred to as a "seed coupon")?

elements.name: survey_churn_referral
elements.title: In 2024, did you receive a coupon from a friend or other person experiencing homelessness?

elements.name: sleeping_situation
elements.title: Where did you stay last night?

choices.text: Outside in a tent (or tent-like structure)
Outside, not in a tent
In a car, truck, or van (smaller vehicle)
In an RV, trailer, or bus/boat (larger vehicle)
In a park (uncovered, like on a bench)
In an overnight shelter (e.g. mission, church, resource shelter, etc.)
In a hotel or motel
In an abandoned building/backyard or storage structure
In a public facility or transit (bus/train station, transit center, airport, hopsital waiting room)
In a tiny home
On public transit (e.g. slept on bus, train, etc.)
In jail or prison
In a hopsital (stayed as a patient overnight)
In a drug or alcohol treatment/detox center
In a friend or family member's house/apartment
Do not know

elements.name: vehicle_amenities
elements.title: Does your vehicle have access to any of the following needs?

elements.name: personal_amenities
elements.title: Do you generally have access to any of the following needs?

elements.name: network_size_instruction
elements.html: Instructions: If the respondent says "hundreds" or "too many" emphasize the "personally know" part of the question. They would need to both recognize each other and know some information about each other.

elements.name: non_family_network_size
elements.title: Other than any family living with you, how many people do you closely know who are also unhoused or experiencing homelessness today?

elements.name: network_instruction
elements.html: Instructions: Please fill in information for each person below. You can add or remove tabs as needed.

elements.name: non_family_network
elements.title: For those {non_family_network_size} people, please fill in as much of the following information as you are able:

choices.text: Outside in a tent (or tent-like structure)
Outside, not in a tent
In a car, truck, or van (smaller vehicle)
In an RV, trailer, or bus/boat (larger vehicle)
In a park (uncovered, like on a bench)
In an overnight shelter (e.g. mission, church, resource shelter, etc.)
In a hotel or motel
In an abandoned building/backyard or storage structure
In a public facility or transit (bus/train station, transit center, airport, hopsital waiting room)
In a tiny home
On public transit (e.g. slept on bus, train, etc.)
In jail or prison
In a hopsital (stayed as a patient overnight)
In a drug or alcohol treatment/detox center
In a friend or family member's house/apartment
Do not know

elements.name: episode_lot_homeless
elements.title: How long have you been homeless this time?
choices: 1 week or more, but less than 1 month
1 month or more, but less than 90 days
90 days or more, but less than 1 year

elements.name: num_episodes
elements.title: Including this time, how many different times have you been homeless in the past 3 years, that is since November 2022?

elements.name: overall_lot_homeless
elements.title: If you added up all the time you have spent experiencing homelessness in the past 3 years, about how long would that be?
elements.description: Feel free to enter any variations of the respondent's answer. For example: 1.5 years, 18 months, 1 year and 6 months.

elements.name: shelter_services
elements.title: In the past 3 years, have you enrolled in an Emergency Shelter or received any other form of housing assistance from an organization that serves people experiencing homelessness? (Includes referrals, vouchers, hygiene support, etc.)

elements.name: shelter_services_details
elements.title: Housing Assistance Services
elements.description: Fill out the table below as much as possible.\nIn case a respondent received a service multiple times, only include the last service received.

elements.name: demographics_instruction
elements.html: INTERVIEWER: Because the respondent has already indicated they are under 18, you may select 0-17 without asking this question.

elements.name: age_group
elements.title: How old are you?

elements.name: gender_id
elements.title: Which of the following best describes your gender? (Select all that apply)

elements.name: ethnicity
elements.title: Are you Hispanic/ Latina/e/o?

elements.name: racial_id
elements.title: Which of the following best describes your racial identity? (Select all that apply)

elements.name: tribal_affil
elements.title: Do you have a Tribal Affiliation? If so, what is it?

elements.name: va_health_eligible_instruction
elements.html: INTERVIEWER: Because the respondent has indicated they are under 18, only ask about family members' status

elements.name: veteran_status
elements.title: Are you or a member of your immediate family a veteran?
choices: Yes, a member of my immediate family is a veteran
Yes, I am a veteran AND a member of my immediate family is a veteran
No, neither I nor a member of my immediate family are veterans

elements.name: va_health_eligible
elements.title: Have you ever received health care of other benefits from a Veterans Administration (VA) center?

elements.name: fleeing_dv
elements.title: Are you currently experiencing homelessness because you are/were fleeing domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking?

elements.name: disabled
elements.title: Do you identify as having a disability?

elements.name: mental_health
elements.title: Do you identify as having a severe mental illness?

elements.name: substance_use
elements.title: Do you identify as having a substance use disorder?

elements.name: household_instruction
elements.html: Please list the initials of all the people in your household (anyone who shares the same dwelling with you)

elements.name: household_members
elements.title: Household Members

templateElements.name: hh_member_gender_id
templateElements.title: Which of the following best describes the gender of {panel.hh_member_initials}?

templateElements.name: hh_member_race
templateElements.title: Which of the following best describes the racial identity of {panel.hh_member_initials}? (Note, you may report more than one group.)

templateElements.name: hh_member_tribal_id
templateElements.title: Does {panel.hh_member_initials} have a Tribal Affiliation? If so, what is their Tribal Affiliation?

templateElements.name: hh_member_disability
templateElements.title: Does {panel.hh_member_initials} identify as having a disability?

templateElements.name: hh_member_smi
templateElements.title: Does {panel.hh_member_initials} identify as having a severe mental illness?

templateElements.name: hh_member_sud
templateElements.title: Does {panel.hh_member_initials} identify as having a substance use disorder?

elements.name: travel_location
elements.title: Where did you travel from today? (Town or City)

elements.name: travel_transport
elements.title: What transportation did you use to come to {location}?

elements.name: travel_time
elements.title: How long did it take you to travel to get to {location}?

elements.name: travel_time_hours
elements.title: Hours

elements.name: travel_time_minutes
elements.title: Minutes

elements.name: travel_distance
elements.title: About how many miles did you travel to {location}?

elements.name: last_stable_loc
elements.title: Where did you live the last time you had stable housing such as an apartment or a house?

elements.name: last_stable_loc_city
elements.title: Which city in King County was it?
choices: Unincorporated King County Other (includes any community not otherwise listed) -

elements.name: last_stable_loc_county
elements.title: Which county in Washington State was it?

elements.name: last_stable_loc_state
elements.title: Which  state in the United States?

elements.name: age_first_hmlss_instruction
elements.html: INTERVIEWER: Because the respondent has indicated they are under 18, you may select 0-17 without asking the question.

elements.name: age_first_hmlss
elements.title: How old were you the first time you experienced homelessness?

elements.name: precipitating_events
elements.title: What events or conditions contributed to you becoming homeless at this time?
choices: Family/friend's housing wouldn't let me stay
Family/friend couldn't afford to let me stay

elements.name: shelter_priorities
elements.title: If you were to seek out a shelter program, what top shelter features would be most important to you? (Please select up to 5)
choices: Close to where I stay now/ In my current community
Enough space to keep my distance from others
Ability to bring my pet/service animal
Ability to move in with a friend
Minimal rules so I can do as I please
Ability to return if I don't stay there one night
On-site health services such as a nurse

elements.name: pet_animal
elements.title: Do you have a pet or animal companion?

elements.name: pet_animal_details
elements.title: Pet Information

templateElements.name: pet_animal_vet_care
templateElements.title: Has {panel.pet_name} seen vet care in last 3 years (such as for wellness visits, vaccines, or an illness)?

templateElements.name: pet_medical_needs
templateElements.title: How long have you been responsible for {panel.pet_name}?

elements.name: deduplication
elements.title: Not counting this time, do you believe you’ve completed this survey in 2026 already?

elements.name: outro_html
elements.html: That completes the questions for today's survey. Thank you so much for your responses and your time. We will now issue the gift card and prepare your coupons to pass out to others in your network who are unsheltered.

elements.name: referral_instruction
elements.html:
Instructions: Please read the following information out loud to the respondent.

At the end of this survey, we will give you referral coupons. Please give them to other people experiencing homelessness. If they come and take our survey using your coupon, we can send you $5 gift cards for each completed referral. To receive these gift cards, we need either a phone number or email address.

elements.name: email_phone_consent
elements.title: Do you consent to receive your gift cards via SMS or email?

choices.text: Email address
Phone number

elements.name: email
elements.title: What's your email address?

elements.name: phone
elements.title: What's your phone number?

elements.name: gift_card_intructions
elements.html: Instructions: The HUB lead will provide the gift card to the respondent. Please record the information below before submitting this survey.

elements.name: gift_card_check
elements.title: Did the respondent receive a Gift Card?

elements.name: gift_card_number
elements.title: Please enter the last 4 digits of the Gift Card:

elements.name: gift_card_2
elements.visibleIf: {gift_card_check} = 'Yes' and {household_members[0].hh_member_age} anyof ['0-6 years old', '7-12 years old', '13-17 years old']
elements.title: Please enter the last 4 digits of the 2nd Gift Card:
elements.description: Note: Families with minor children receive two gift cards.
